t: Job 6
Job: My Complaint Is Just
Then*p Job answered and said:
“Oh,*pn that my grief were fully weighed, And*ld my calamity laid with it on the scales!
For*ld then it would be heavier than the sand of the sea— Therefore*ld my words have been rash.
For*ld the arrows of the Almighty are*i within me; My*ld spirit drinks in their poison; The*ld terrors of God are arrayed against me.
Does*ld the wild donkey bray when it has grass, Or*ld does the ox low over its fodder?
Can*ld flavorless food be eaten without salt? Or*ld is there any*i taste in the white of an egg?
My*ld soul refuses to touch them; They*ld are*i as loathsome food to me.
“Oh,*ln that I might have my request, That*ld God would grant me*i the thing that I long for!
That*ld it would please God to crush me, That*ld He would loose His hand and cut me off!
Then*ld I would still have comfort; Though*ld in anguish I would exult, He*ld will not spare; For*ld I have not concealed the words of the Holy One.
“What*ln strength do I have, that I should hope? And*ld what is*i my end, that I should prolong my life?
Is*ild my strength the strength of stones? Or*ld is my flesh bronze?
Is*ild my help not within me? And*ld is success driven from me?
“To*ln him who is afflicted, kindness should*i be*i shown*i by his friend, Even*ld though he forsakes the fear of the Almighty.
My*ld brothers have dealt deceitfully like a brook, Like*ld the streams of the brooks that pass away,
Which*ld are dark because of the ice, And*ild into which the snow vanishes.
When*ld it is warm, they cease to flow; When*ld it is hot, they vanish from their place.
The*ld paths of their way turn aside, They*ld go nowhere and perish.
The*ld caravans of Tema look, The*ld travelers of Sheba hope for them.
They*ld are disappointed because they were confident; They*ld come there and are confused.
For*ld now you are nothing, You*ld see terror and are afraid.
Did*ld I ever say, ‘Bring something*i to me’? Or,*ld ‘Offer a bribe for me from your wealth’?
Or,*ld ‘Deliver me from the enemy’s hand’? Or,*ld ‘Redeem me from the hand of oppressors’?
“Teach*ln me, and I will hold my tongue; Cause*ld me to understand wherein I have erred.
How*ld forceful are right words! But*ld what does your arguing prove?
Do*ld you intend to rebuke my*i words, And*ld the speeches of a desperate one, which*i are*i as wind?
Yes,*ld you overwhelm the fatherless, And*ld you undermine your friend.
Now*ld therefore, be pleased to look at me; For*ld I would never lie to your face.
Yield*ld now, let there be no injustice! Yes,*ld concede, my righteousness still stands!
Is*ld there injustice on my tongue? Cannot*ld my taste discern the unsavory?
